thread.title: Clearing 2015: 'I thought: why not go for it?'
thread.title_full: Clearing 2015: 'I thought: why not go for it?' - Telegraph

author: Interview by Ava Meggle
title: Clearing 2015: 'I thought: why not go for it?'
text: Leanne Town, who graduated in web design and marketing from the University of Northampton two years ago, shares the ups and downs of the Clearing process, and how it turned out to be a successful experience for her. • Download the Telegraph's Clearing app for iPhone and Android From the beginning, Clearing seemed like a chance for me to open up my career opportunities. At the time, I was working for a mobile beauty business. I had been feeling in the need for change, and decided to get a new job. I soon realised how helpful qualifications can be when seeking employment, and I didn't have any grades except for my GCSEs. The idea to go to university progressively took shape, and my mother's support definitely encouraged me to go for it. Ucas notified me I had to go through Clearing. I didn’t know much about the process, and I thought I probably wouldn’t get in, but I decided to give it a go. I enrolled on a media production course at the University of Northampton . However, I had to choose a second subject because this degree was only available as a Joint Honours. With a little help from the admissions team, I went through all the different courses I could do alongside media production, and we agreed on web design. Unfortunately, it turned out that the media production course was full. I felt very disappointed. As we started scrolling again through remaining courses, I stumbled upon one that particularly caught my attention: marketing. The course encompassed many fields in business, it went nicely with web design, and I wasn’t sure what to do anyway. So I thought: why not go for it? I felt very lucky to get a place, because it was one of Northampton’s biggest courses. And guess what? I actually preferred marketing to web design. I absolutely loved it. It opened my eyes to so many different things about consumption and business. I realised how easily we get influenced through simple marketing strategies, which truly fascinated me. It’s been really good studying at Northampton, too. I met really nice people, and the campus organises a great variety of extra curricular activities. The staff were extremely helpful and ensured that my Clearing process worked out smoothly. I knew I could rely on them to guide me through every step, by telling me what I needed to do and where I needed to go, etc. I don’t remember being stressed at all, either. I think the whole process was quite simple. If you apply for Clearing, just make sure you start the process as soon as possible. And don’t get put off by it. I didn’t have A-levels grades, but it opened my chances to go to university, thanks to letters of recommendation and references. And, as things turned out, I can say it was definitely worth keeping faith in. • Step-by-step guide to A-level Results Day • Step-by-step guide to Clearing • Step-by-step guide to Adjustment • Download the Telegraph's Clearing app for iPhone and Android Follow @telegraph
